results.title: Return journey: a tribute to Burke and Wills
results.creator_credit: John Sherman, William Sterling and Albatross Film Pty Ltd
results.brief_description: Re-enacts the 1861 expedition of Burke and Wills, with emphasis on the return journey north across the continent of Australia. Relates the rigours and heartbreaks of the expedition, culminating in the deaths of the explorers at Cooper Creek.

results.title: Return journey
results.creator_credit: Ian Potts, Arts Council of Great Britain and Worktown Production
results.brief_description: The film traces the development and usage of the documentary photograph through the work of three photographers, Humphrey Spender, Derek Smith and Jimmy Forsyth. It presents a unique record of English working class life from the 30’s to the 50’s. Narration by Ray Gosling.

results.title: Return home [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Ray Argall, Cristina Pozzan and Musical Films
results.brief_description: Noel, divorced and middle-aged, takes a break from his high pressure job in a big corporation to visit his brother, who, with his wife, is struggling to hang onto a barely viable small business - a service station in Adelaide. Gary, the 19 year old apprentice is struggling to come to terms with the complexities of life as an emerging adult and befriends Noel. Before long, Noel rediscovers the pleasures of family and is revitalised. After his return to Melbourne, his brother Gary and wife Judy, reassess their own lives and begin to see their own potential. Noel eventually returns to Adelaide for good; his journey for happiness, security and a future filled with promise is finally over. Ray Argall’s direction gives form and substance to everyday lives, with a sense of naturalism apparent. Stars Dennis Coard, Frankie J. Holden, Ben Mendelsohn and Micki Camilleri. Cinematography by Mandy Walker. Also available on VHS [305270].

results.title: Return from Witch Mountain
results.creator_credit: John Hough, Jerome Courtland, Ron Miller and Walt Disney Animation Studios
results.brief_description: Sequel to “Escape to Witch Mountain” this family film is full of adventure and fantasy as Tia (Kim Richards) and her brother Tony (Ike Eisenmann), both who have supernatural powers, arrive on Planet Earth for a holiday. Dr Gannon (Christopher Lee) and his offsider Letha (Bette Davis) are trying to develop a mind-control device and when the evil Dr Gannon learns of Tony’s special powers, he kidnaps him, leaving it to Tia with her telepathic powers, and a motley gang of youngsters, to rescue Tony.

results.title: Return from the road
results.brief_description: Short film starring US comedian Harvey Korman as a travelling salesman just returned from a long sales trip, tired, hungry and frustrated. With an unco-operative wife who won’t cook and then makes him sleep on the couch, he dreams of what might have been. News of the imminent arrival of his mother-in-law turns his thoughts to the road again.

results.title: Return
results.brief_description: Static images of an old country house are combined with voices of the past to evocative effect. Haunting and nostalgic, ‘Return’ conveys the life that exists in old, abandoned places.

results.title: Retro gaming
results.brief_description: Before NBA Jam, there was Atari’s Basketball. Released just in time for the arcade heyday of the early 1980s, it was the first basketball game to use a trackball controller and a 45-degree angled side view.

constellations_primary.name: Representation of women in videogames
constellations_primary.description: Ms Pac-Man is the first famous female game protagonist, but let's face it – she's just Pac-Man with a bow. This Constellation looks at the history of female representation in videogames.

results.description:
Before NBA Jam, there was Atari’s Basketball. Released just in time for the arcade heyday of the early 1980s, it was the first basketball game to use a trackball controller and a 45-degree angled side view. Not only did this become part of the playbook for basketball games that followed, but Basketball was also the first sports game where the pixelated sprites that players controlled actually looked like people. The game unit’s neon graphic design is also uniquely of its time and reflects the burgeoning videogame aesthetic.

In another first, Ms Pac-Man hit arcades in 1982 and featured the first famous female game protagonist, though she started out as male character. Designed by a group of Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) dropouts, Ms Pac-Man was originally a modification for Pac-Man, called Crazy Otto. Due to legal action by Atari, the MIT group presented their modification kit to the North American Pac-Man distributor, who bought it and helped evolve the concept into Ms Pac-Man. It featured new mazes and improved the unpredictability of enemies to make it more challenging.
description_for_label:
Before NBA Jam, there was Atari’s Basketball. Released just in time for the arcade heyday of the early 1980s, it was the first basketball game to use a trackball controller and a 45-degree angled side view. Not only did this become part of the playbook for basketball games that followed, but Basketball was also the first sports game where the pixelated sprites that players controlled actually looked like people. The game unit’s neon graphic design is also uniquely of its time and reflects the burgeoning videogame aesthetic.

In another first, Ms Pac-Man hit arcades in 1982 and featured the first famous female game protagonist, though she started out as male character. Designed by a group of Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) dropouts, Ms Pac-Man was originally a modification for Pac-Man, called Crazy Otto. Due to legal action by Atari, the MIT group presented their modification kit to the North American Pac-Man distributor, who bought it and helped evolve the concept into Ms Pac-Man. It featured new mazes and improved the unpredictability of enemies to make it more challenging.

results.title: Retirement villages: a consumer guide
results.creator_credit: Garry McKechnie, Andrea Philipp and Village Communique
results.brief_description: Buying into a retirement village is a big step and one that leads to further, more complicated issues. This series of 3 videos and booklet attempts to work through these issues and help make the final decision about buying into a retirement village, an informed one. The 3 tapes cover lifestyle, financial and legal issues. The book provides a step by step guide to the process as a whole.

results.title: Retirement income perils
results.creator_credit: Sally Wiadrowski and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: In this “4 Corners” special, reporter Chris Masters investigates an area which is causing plenty of grey hairs - Retirement Investment Planning - RIP. This is an overview of the efficacy of superannuation savings and how it will or will not allow people to live comfortably after retirement.
